engagementHook.title: Nature's Speed Boosters
engagementHook.content: Without enzymes, the chemical reactions necessary for life would take millions of years to complete. One enzyme in your body—carbonic anhydrase—can process 1 million molecules per second. Without it, you wouldn't be able to transport carbon dioxide efficiently, making exercise—and life as we know it—impossible.

keyConcepts.definition: The minimum amount of energy required to start a chemical reaction. Enzymes lower this barrier without being consumed.

The property of enzymes to catalyse specific reactions due to the precise shape and chemical properties of their active sites.
The theory that the enzyme's active site changes shape slightly to better fit the substrate upon binding, enhancing catalytic efficiency.

contentSections.title: Enzymes as Biological Catalysts
contentSections.content:
Enzymes are globular proteins that act as biological catalysts, speeding up chemical reactions without being consumed. Each enzyme catalyses a specific reaction due to the unique shape of its active site.

Key properties:

  • Highly specific—each enzyme acts on particular substrates
  • Reusable—not permanently changed by the reaction
  • Work best under specific temperature and pH conditions
  • Can be regulated by inhibitors and activators

contentSections.title: Models of Enzyme Action
contentSections.content: Two models explain how enzymes interact with substrates. The lock-and-key model suggests the active site is rigid, while the induced fit model describes the active site as flexible, changing shape to accommodate the substrate.
keyPoints: Lock-and-key: Rigid active site matching substrate shape
Induced fit: Flexible active site adjusts to substrate
Modern view favours induced fit for most enzymes
contentSections.example: Hexokinase undergoes large conformational changes when binding glucose.

contentSections.title: Factors Affecting Enzyme Activity
contentSections.content:
Enzyme activity is influenced by environmental conditions:

  • Temperature: Activity increases with temperature up to an optimum, then decreases as enzymes denature at high temperatures.
  • pH: Each enzyme has an optimal pH; deviations cause loss of activity due to changes in ionisation of amino acid residues.
  • Substrate concentration: Reaction rate increases with substrate concentration until all active sites are saturated.
  • Enzyme concentration: Directly proportional to reaction rate when substrate is in excess.

Most human enzymes work best at 37°C and pH 7.4, reflecting body conditions.

multipleChoice.question: According to the induced fit model, what happens when a substrate binds to an enzyme?
options: The enzyme remains rigid and unchanged
The active site changes shape to better fit the substrate
The substrate permanently attaches to the enzyme
The enzyme is destroyed after the reaction
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: The active site changes shape to better fit the substrate

multipleChoice.question: Why do enzymes denature at high temperatures?
options: Hydrogen bonds maintaining tertiary structure are disrupted
The substrate concentration becomes too high
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Hydrogen bonds maintaining tertiary structure are disrupted

multipleChoice.question: What is the primary role of enzymes in biochemical reactions?
options: To provide energy for the reaction
To lower the activation energy required
To increase the temperature of the reaction
To change the pH of the cellular environment
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: To lower the activation energy required
